Comment: As normal as ever.
I reply normally - I don't play any openings - my favourite is 1. d5 for white - I rely on tactics to win the game.
Attacking the e5 pawn.
Subsequently defending.
This; I believe, is the scotch. I have no further replies than exd4.
Now, I expected for my opponent to take the pawn, however, he did not.
Probably attacking f7; I do not see this move as a beginner's move; rather, a sensible one.
I protect my d4 pawn and develop my bishop.
c3. I am somewhat unfamiliar to the Scotch, so I took innocently ...
... not knowing that I was to fall for a beginner's (?) trap.
Not taking the bishop would be awkward, but taking the bishop isn't much better.
Leaving d5 a forking square.
This forks the unprotected bishop on c5.
Hoisting my king back to safety.
The bishop goes.
I take the pawn before the pawn takes me.

The bishop takes its long laser aim at g7. Is this position in any way better for white - this disables my ability to castle, but is this strictly better for white? Black is still a pawn up. Take a moment to look at this position.
Chasing away the queen and opening the lines for my bishop - note that Bxg7 is irrelevant as the queen is attacked.
The threat on g7 is renewed. Note that after 10. Qh5+?! g6 the queen is attacked, thus the rook on h8 is safe.
Attacking the queen and preventing 11. Bxg7.
